channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Scientist Who Had Claimed Stem Cell Breakthrough Resigns From Japanese Research Institute
item.description: The institute said the researcher had failed in the three months it gave her to replicate what she had portrayed as a simple way to make stem cells.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Cuba Thaw Lets Rest of Latin America Warm to Washington
item.description: Leaders who have consistently lambasted the United States and President Obama abruptly changed course, praising the policy shift on Cuba.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: FIFA to Release Redacted Report on Corruption in World Cup Bidding
item.description: Sepp Blatter, the president of the governing body of soccer, said the findings by an ethics committee would be edited to protect privacy and investigations.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN

item.title: Mandy Rice-Davies, Figure in Britain’s Profumo Affair, Dies at 70
item.description: Ms. Rice-Davies achieved notoriety in 1963 in one of Britain’s most spectacular sex scandals, which brought down a cabinet minister.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Mandy Rice-Davies leaving court in 1963 after testifying for the prosecution against Stephen Ward, who also played a role in Profumo scandal. Ms. Rice-Davies has died at age 70.

item.title: 8 Australian Children Are Killed in Reported Stabbing
item.description: Their bodies were discovered in a house in Manoora, a suburb of Cairns, and a woman believed to be the mother of seven of them was seriously injured.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: The police outside a house in a suburb of Cairns, Australia, where the bodies were discovered.

item.title: Russia to Seek 10-Year Sentence for Putin Critic
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, a prominent opposition figure, and his brother, Oleg, were accused of stealing almost $500,000 from two firms.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Dozens of Militants Killed in Pakistan in Wake of Taliban Attack on School
item.description: Pakistani forces stepped up operations against insurgents near the Afghan border after 148 students and staff members died in a siege in Peshawar.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Ex-City Official and Property Tycoon Are Convicted in Hong Kong Graft Trial
item.description: The trial suggested the cozy ties between the city’s business elite and career officials who rose through the ranks of the British colonial government.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Under Xi, China’s Wave of ‘Weird Architecture’ May Have Peaked
item.description: Ever since President Xi Jinping issued his admonishment against the rise of outlandish and exorbitant buildings across China, government officials, planners and architects have been scrambling to figure out what it means for them.
item.dc:creator: By CAO LI
item.media:description: An artist's rendition of the Chaoyang Park Plaza development, left, which developers have warned may be the last oddly shaped buildings constructed in Beijing for some time.

item.title: 8 Children Found Stabbed to Death in Australia
item.description: Their bodies were discovered in a house in Manoora, a suburb of Cairns, and a woman believed to be their mother was seriously injured.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Outside a house located in a suburb of Cairns, where the bodies of eight children were found.

item.title: Pakistani Forces Kill 59 Militants Near Afghan Border
item.description: Pakistani jets and ground forces killed 59 militants in a northwestern tribal region near the Afghan border, the army said Friday, days after Taliban fighters killed 148 people in a school massacre.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: South Korea Disbands Party Sympathetic to North
item.description: The court ruling against the United Progressive Party marked a political victory for President Park Geun-hye, who had sought to have the party dissolved.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With Families Refusing to Return, ‘Naked’ Officials Are Demoted
item.description: The series of demotions represents a new phase in the Communist Party’s campaign against “naked officials,” those who have sent their families to live overseas.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: A protest outside a courthouse in Langfang, China, where a former senior official, Liu Tienan, was sentenced to life in prison for bribery this month. China's anticorruption initiatives have wide public backing.

item.title: U.S. Frees Last of the ‘Cuban Five,’ Part of a 1990s Spy Ring
item.description: Three members of the Cuban Five — part of a spy ring that infiltrated exile groups in Florida in the 1990s — were released from prison as part of the sudden diplomatic thaw in relations.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: A billboard in Havana with Fidel Castro and the Cuban Five, left, spies who infiltrated exile groups in South Florida and who were also freed on Wednesday.

item.title: Journey to Reconciliation Visited Worlds of Presidents, Popes and Spies
item.description: The deal that restored full diplomatic relations between the United States and Cuba ultimately rested with a spy swap.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Obama speaking with Cuba’s president, Raúl Castro, on Tuesday. On Wednesday, Mr. Obama ordered the restoration of full diplomatic relations.

item.title: 8 Children Killed in Home in Northern Australia
item.description: Eight dead children and a woman suffering from stab wounds were found inside a home, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Liberia Will Proceed With Senate Vote Delayed by Ebola
item.description: An election repeatedly delayed because of the epidemic and other challenges will be held on Saturday, but critics worry whether voting will fair and safe.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIR MacDOUGALL

item.title: News Analysis: A Diplomatic Triumph in Cuba Comes With a Challenge in North Korea
item.description: Cuba and North Korea are posing opposite challenges for the Obama administration — with Havana experimenting with integration, and Pyongyang brandishing a new weapon.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, center, at a ceremony Wednesday for the third anniversary of his father’s death.

item.title: The Revolution Fidel Castro Began Evolves Under His Brother
item.description: Fidel Castro, a venerable figure to generations of Cubans, is fading into history as his more pragmatic brother, Raúl, reshapes the nation.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: Students with a portrait of Fidel Castro at a march in Havana in September for spies who were imprisoned. Castro has not appeared in public for months.

item.title: Obama Intends to Lift Several Restrictions Against Cuba on His Own
item.description: Administration officials said travel and commerce restrictions could be lifted as early as next month.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Obama at the White House’s Hanukkah party. Administration officials said travel and commerce restrictions against Cuba could be lifted next month.
